verses.sanskrit:
dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca
dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre
samavetā yuyutsavaḥ
māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva
kim akurvata sañjaya
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
dhṛtarāṣṭras uvāca
dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre
samavetās yuyutsavas
māmakās pāṇḍavās caiva
kim akurvata sañjaya
verses.prabhupada: Dhṛtarāṣṭra said: O Sañjaya, after my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu assembled in the place of pilgrimage at Kurukṣetra, desiring to fight, what did they do?
verses.winthrop:
`Dhritarashtra spoke:
When they were in the field
of virtue, in the field of the Kurus,
Assembled together, desiring to fight,
What did my army and that of the
Sons of Pandu do, Sanjaya?
verses.mitchell: Dhritarashtra said: On the field of justice, the field of the Kurus, mine (his sons) and the sons of Pandu were gathered together, desirous of battle. What did they do, Sanjaya?

verses.sanskrit:
sañjaya uvāca
dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṃ
vyūḍhaṃ duryodhanas tadā
ācāryam upasaṅgamya
rājā vacanam abravīt
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
sañjayas uvāca
dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkam
vyūḍham duryodhanas tadā
ācāryam upasaṅgamya
rājā vacanam abravīt
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: O King, after looking over the army arranged in military formation by the sons of Pāṇḍu, King Duryodhana went to his teacher and spoke the following words.
verses.winthrop:
Sanjaya spoke:
Seeing indeed the army
Of the sons of Pandu arrayed,
King Duryodhana, approaching his
Master (Drona),
Spoke these words:
verses.mitchell: Sanjaya said: Having seen the Pandava army arranged, Duryodhana then met with (his) martial guru. The king spoke words.

verses.sanskrit:
paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām
ācārya mahatīṃ camūm
vyūḍhāṃ drupada-putreṇa
tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
paśyaitām pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīm camūm
vyūḍhām drupada-putreṇa
tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
verses.prabhupada: O my teacher, behold the great army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, so expertly arranged by your intelligent disciple the son of Drupada.
verses.winthrop:
Behold O Master, this great army
Of the sons of Pandu
Arrayed by the sons of Drupada,
Wise by your instruction.
verses.mitchell: Master, just see the expansive army of the sons of Pandu, arranged by the son of Drupada, your intelligent disciple.

verses.sanskrit:
atra śūrā maheṣvāsā
bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi
yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca
drupadaś ca mahā-rathaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
atra śūrās maheṣvāsās
bhīma-arjuna-samās yudhi
yuyudhānas virāṭas ca
drupadas ca mahā-rathas
verses.prabhupada: Here in this army are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhīma and Arjuna: great fighters like Yuyudhāna, Virāṭa and Drupada.
verses.winthrop:
Here are heroes, mighty archers,
Equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna,
Yuyudhana and Virata,
And Drupada, the great warrior,
verses.mitchell: Here (are) great heroic bowmen, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna: Yuyudhana, Virtata, and the great chariot fighter, Drupada, too.

verses.sanskrit:
dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ
kāśi-rājaś ca vīryavān
purujit kunti-bhojaś ca
śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
dhṛṣṭaketus cekitānas
kāśi-rājas ca vīryavān
purujit kunti-bhojas ca
śaibyas ca nara-puṅgavas
verses.prabhupada: There are also great heroic, powerful fighters like Dhṛṣṭaketu, Cekitāna, Kāśirāja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja and Śaibya.
verses.winthrop:
Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana,
And the valorous King of Kash,
Purojit and Kuntibhoja
And Shaibya, bull among men.
verses.mitchell: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, Kashiraj, and Viryavan. Purujit, Kuntiboja, and Shaibya, too, (is a) bull among men.

verses.sanskrit:
yudhāmanyuś ca vikrānta
uttamaujāś ca vīryavān
saubhadro draupadeyāś ca
sarva eva mahā-rathāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yudhāmanyus ca vikrāntas
uttamaujās ca vīryavān
saubhadras draupadeyās ca
sarva eva mahā-rathās
verses.prabhupada: There are the mighty Yudhāmanyu, the very powerful Uttamaujā, the son of Subhadrā and the sons of Draupadī. All these warriors are great chariot fighters.
verses.winthrop:
And mighty Yudhamanyu
And the valorous Uttamaujas;
The son of Subhadra and the sons of Draupadi,
All indeed great warriors.
verses.mitchell: ...and the courageoous Yudhamanyu, Uttamauja, the virile son of Subhadra, and the sons of Draupadi (are) all mighty warriors, too.

verses.sanskrit:
asmākaṃ tu viśiṣṭā ye
tān nibodha dvi-jottama
nāyakā mama sainyasya
saṃjñārthaṃ tān bravīmi te
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
asmākam tu viśiṣṭās ye
tān nibodha dvi-jottama
nāyakās mama sainyasya
saṃjñārtham tān bravīmi te
verses.prabhupada: But for your information, O best of the brāhmaṇas, let me tell you about the captains who are especially qualified to lead my military force.
verses.winthrop:
Those of ours who are indeed distinguished,
Know them! O highest of the Twiceborn,
The leaders of my army
I name for you by proper names:
verses.mitchell: But our(s) who (are) distinguished! Consider them, O best of the twice-born. (They are) the leaders of my army. I am declaring them to you for the sake of naming.

verses.sanskrit:
bhavān bhīṣmaś ca karṇaś ca
kṛpaś ca samitiñjayaḥ
aśvatthāmā vikarṇaś ca
saumadattis tathaiva ca
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
bhavān bhīṣmas ca karṇas ca
kṛpas ca samitiñjayas
aśvatthāmā vikarṇas ca
saumadattis tathā eva ca
verses.prabhupada: There are personalities like you, Bhīṣma, Karṇa, Kṛpa, Aśvatthāmā, Vikarṇa and the son of Somadatta called Bhūriśravā, who are always victorious in battle.
verses.winthrop:
Your Lordship and Bhishma and Karna
and Kripa, always victorious in battle,
Ashvatthama and Vikarna
and the son of Somadatta also;
verses.mitchell: (There is) your honor, Bhishma, Karna, and the ever-victorious Kripa. (There is) Ashvatthama, Vikarna, and then also Saumadatti, too.

verses.sanskrit: anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ sarve yuddha-viśāradāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
anye ca bahavas śūrās
mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitās
nānā-śastra-praharaṇās
sarve yuddha-viśāradās
verses.prabhupada: There are many other heroes who are prepared to lay down their lives for my sake. All of them are well equipped with different kinds of weapons, and all are experienced in military science.
verses.winthrop:
And many other heroes
whose lives are risked for my sake,
attacking with various weapons,
all skilled in battle.
verses.mitchell: And (there are) many other heroes, (their) lives abandoned for my sake, (possessing) various striking weapons, all skilled in battle.

verses.sanskrit:
aparyāptaṃ tad asmākaṃ
balaṃ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam
paryāptaṃ tv idam eteṣāṃ
balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
aparyāptam tad asmākam
balam bhīṣma-abhirakṣitam
paryāptam tu idam eteṣām
balam bhīma-abhirakṣitam
verses.prabhupada: Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhīṣma, whereas the strength of the Pāṇḍavas, carefully protected by Bhīma, is limited.
verses.winthrop:
Sufficient is that force of ours
Guarded by Bhishma;
Insufficient though is
The force guarded by Bhima.
verses.mitchell: That (force) is inferior to ours, (which is) protected by Bhishma. But, this (force) is superior to theirs, (which is) proteced by Bhima, is superior.

translation and grammar notes.comment: Winthrop struggles with (a)paryāptaṃ 'inferior' here. MW gives us 'unlimited; unbounded as a possible alternative, but Mahabharata (see references) offers the word in other places when making comparisons, and it clearly means 'inferior'. Even the syntax is the same (nominative + genitive = not superior). It is proposed here, following suit with Arjuna's humorous remark in ref (3), that the accompanying genitive is a genitive of comparison rather than a possessive pronoun. This also clears up the tad/idam confusion.
Links: avāpya sarvaśastrāṇi mudito vāsavātmajaḥ mene sarvān mahīpālān aparyāptān svatejasā /
(Having obtained all the weapons, the son of Indra) considered all the earth protectors inferior to his own power.
na caite tava paryāptā jñāne dharmārthayostathā vikrame cāpyaparyāptāḥ pāṇḍavān prati bhārata
These of your(s) are not even superior (paryāptā) in knowledge, religious merit, and also they're inferior (aparyāptāḥ) to the Pandavas in courage, O scion of Bharata.
arjunaḥ pratyuvācedaṃ kṛṣṇamakliṣṭakāriṇam mamāpyetāv aparyāptau karṇaśalyau janārdana
Arjuna, who is never wearied in action, responded to Krishna, 'For me, both Karna and Shalya (put together) are inferior, Janardana.'

verses.sanskrit:
ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu
yathā bhāgam avasthitāḥ
bhīṣmam evābhirakṣantu
bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu
yathā bhāgam avasthitās
bhīṣmam eva abhirakṣantu
bhavantas sarva eva hi
verses.prabhupada: All of you must now give full support to Grandfather Bhīṣma, as you stand at your respective strategic points of entrance into the phalanx of the army.
verses.winthrop:
And in all movements,
Stationed each in his respective place,
All of you, indeed,
Protect Bhishma!
verses.mitchell: At all points of entry, positioned according to your share, you all must indeed protect Bhishma!

verses.sanskrit:
tasya sañjanayan harṣaṃ
kuru-vṛddhaḥ pitā-mahaḥ
siṃha-nādaṃ vinadyocchaiḥ
śaṅkhaṃ dadhmau pratāpavān
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
tasya sañjanayan harṣam
kuru-vṛddhas pitā-mahas
siṃha-nādam vinadya-ucchaiḥ
śaṅkham dadhmau pratāpavān
verses.prabhupada: Then Bhīṣma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, the grandfather of the fighters, blew his conchshell very loudly, making a sound like the roar of a lion, giving Duryodhana joy.
verses.winthrop:
Making him (Duryodhana) happy,
The aged Kuru, his grandsire,
Roaring like a lion,
Blew his conch horn powerfully.
verses.mitchell: Causing his (Duryodhana's) delight, the Kuru elder, the powerful grandfather, after loudly belting out a lion's roar, blew his conchshell.

verses.sanskrit:
tataḥ śaṅkhāś ca bheryaś ca
paṇavānaka-gomukhāḥ
sahasaivābhyahanyanta
sa śabdas tumulobhavat
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
tatas śaṅkhās ca bheryas ca
paṇava-ānaka-go-mukhās
sahasā-eva-abhyahanyanta
sa śabdas tumulas abhavat
verses.prabhupada: After that, the conchshells, drums, bugles, trumpets and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.
verses.winthrop:
And thereupon the conch horns and the kettledrums,
The cymbals, drums and trumpets
All at once sounded.
The upraor was tremendous.
verses.mitchell: Then, conchshells, drums, kettledrums, and trumpets were suddenly resounding.  The sound was tumultuous.

verses.sanskrit:
tataḥ śvetair hayair yukte
mahati syandane sthitau
mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaś caiva
divyau śaṅkhau pradaghmatuḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
tatas śvetais hayais yukte
mahati syandane sthitau
mādhavas pāṇḍavas ca eva
divyau śaṅkhau pradaghmatus
verses.prabhupada: On the other side, both Lord Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna, stationed on a great chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their transcendental conchshells.
verses.winthrop:
Then, standing in the great chariot
Yoked with white horses,
Krishna and Arjuna
Sounded forth their divine conch horns.
verses.mitchell: Then, situated on a great chariot yoked with white horses, Madhava (Krishna) and the Pandava (Arjuna) blew their divine conchshells.

verses.sanskrit:
pāñca-janyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo
devadattaṃ dhanañjayaḥ
pauṇḍraṃ dadhmau mahā-śaṅkhaṃ
bhīma-karmā vṛkodaraḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
pāñca-janyam hṛṣīkeśas
deva-dattam dhanañjayas
pauṇḍram dadhmau mahā-śaṅkham
bhīma-karmā vṛkodaras
verses.prabhupada: Lord Kṛṣṇa blew His conchshell, called Pāñcajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhīma, the voracious eater and performer of herculean tasks, blew his terrific conchshell, called Pauṇḍra.
verses.winthrop:
Krishna blew his Panchajanya;
Arjuna blew Devadata,
While Bhima, terrible in action,
Blew the great conch horn Paundra.
verses.mitchell: Hrishikesha (Krishna), the Panchajanya. Dhananjaya (Arjuna), the Devadatta. The great conch Paundra, the fearsome Vrikodara (Bhima) blew.

verses.sanskrit:
ananta-vijayaṃ rājā
kuntī-putro yudhiṣṭhiraḥ
nakulaḥ sahadevaś ca
sughoṣa-maṇi-puṣpakau
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
ananta-vijayam rājā
kuntī-putras yudhiṣṭhiras
nakulas sahadevas ca
sughoṣa-maṇi-puṣpakau
verses.prabhupada: King Yudhiṣṭhira, the son of Kuntī, blew his conchshell, the Ananta-vijaya, and Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughoṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka.
verses.winthrop:
King Yudhishthira,
Son of Kunti, blew Anantavijaya;
Nakula and Sahadeva
Blew Sughosa and Manipushpaka.
verses.mitchell: The king, son of Kunti, Yudhishthira (blew) Anantajaya. Nakula and Sahadeva, the Sughosha and Manipushpaka.

verses.sanskrit:
kāśyaś ca parameṣvāsaḥ
śikhaṇḍī ca mahārathaḥ
dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaś ca
sātyakiś cāparājitaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
kāśyas ca parameṣvāsas
śikhaṇḍī ca mahārathas
dhṛṣṭa-dyumnas virāṭas ca
sātyakis ca aparājitaḥ
verses.prabhupada: That great archer the King of Kāśī, the great fighter Śikhaṇḍī, Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa, the unconquerable Sātyaki,
verses.winthrop:
And the King of Kashi, supreme archer,
And Shikhandi, that great warrior, Dhrishtadyumna and Virata
And Satyaki, the invicible;
verses.mitchell: The king of Kashi, a supreme archer, and Shikhandi, a mighty warrior. Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the invincible one.

verses.sanskrit:
drupado draupadeyāś ca
sarvaśaḥ pṛthivī-pate
saubhadraś ca mahābāhuḥ
śaṅkhān dadhmuḥ pṛthak-pṛthak
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
drupadas draupadeyās ca
sarvaśas pṛthivī-pate
saubhadras ca mahā-bāhus
śaṅkhān dadhmus pṛthak-pṛthak
verses.prabhupada: Drupada, the sons of Draupadī, and others, O King, such as the mighty-armed son of Subhadrā, all blew their respective conchshells.
verses.winthrop:
Drupada and the sons of Draupai
All together, O Lord of the Earth,
And the strong armed son of Subhadra
Blew their conch horns, each his own.
verses.mitchell: Drupada, and the sons of Draupadi all together, O ruler of the Earth, and the son of mighty-armed Subhadra blew (their conchshells), one by one.

verses.sanskrit:
sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ
hṛdayāni vyadārayat
nabhaś ca pṛthivīṃ caiva
tumulobhyanunādayan
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
sa ghoṣas dhārta-rāṣṭrāṇām
hṛdayāni vyadārayat
nabhas ca pṛthivīm ca eva
tumulas abhyanunādayan
verses.prabhupada: The blowing of these different conchshells became uproarious. Vibrating both in the sky and on the earth, it shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
verses.winthrop:
The noise burst asunder
The hearts of the sons of Dhritarashtra,
And the tumult caused
The sky and the earth to resound.
verses.mitchell: The sound caused the hearts of the Dhartarashtras to tear open, and both the sky and the earth to reverberate.

verses.sanskrit:
atha vyavasthitān dṛṣṭvā
dhārtarāṣṭrān kapi-dhvajaḥ
pravṛtte śastra-saṃpāte
dhanur udyamya pāṇḍavaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
atha vyavasthitān dṛṣṭvā
dhārta-rāṣṭrān kapi-dhvajas
pravṛtte śastra-saṃpāte
dhanus udyamya pāṇḍavas
verses.prabhupada: At that time Arjuna, the son of Pāṇḍu, seated in the chariot bearing the flag marked with Hanumān, took up his bow and prepared to shoot his arrows.
verses.winthrop:
Then, Arjuna, having seen the sons of Dhritarashtra
Drawn up in battle array,
Raised his bow as the clash of weapons began.
verses.mitchell: Then, the son of Pandu, the bearer of the monkey banner (Arjuna), seeing the Dhritarashtras positioned, (and) raising his bow when the collision of weapons (the battle) was commenced...
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: Placing an action within a locative absolute here might be giving us and imperfective aspect to the commencement of the battle. Perhaps, 'while the battle was commencing' would be better.

verses.sanskrit:
hṛṣīkeśaṃ tadā vākyam
idam āha mahī-pate
senayor ubhayor madhye
rathaṃ sthāpaya me 'cyuta
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
hṛṣīkeśam tadā vākyam
idam āha mahī-pate
senayos ubhayos madhye
ratham sthāpaya me acyuta
verses.prabhupada: O King, after looking at the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra drawn in military array, Arjuna then spoke to Lord Kṛṣṇa these words.
verses.winthrop:
Arjuna then spoke these words to Krishna:
O Lord of the earth,
Cause my chariot to stand in the middle
Between the two armies, Imperishable One,
verses.mitchell: O Lord of the earth, at that time, he uttered this statement to Hrishikesha (Krishna): Station my chariot between the two armies, infallible one.

verses.sanskrit:
yāvad etān nirikṣe 'haṃ
yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān
kair mayā saha yoddhavyam
asmin raṇa-samudyame
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yāvad etān nirikṣe aham
yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān
kais mayā saha yoddhavyam
asmin raṇa-samudyame
verses.prabhupada: Arjuna said: O infallible one, please draw my chariot between the two armies so that I may see those present here, who desire to fight, and with whom I must contend in this great trial of arms.
verses.winthrop:
Until I behold these warriors,
Battle-hungry and arrayed.
With whom should I fight
In undertaking this battle?
verses.mitchell: ...in order that I (will) see these stationed (troops), desirous of battle. With whom (is there to be) a battle with me in this great undertaking of war?

Translation and Grammar Notes.Translation: Apte gives the following for yāvat: (b) just, then, in the meantime (denoting an action intended to be done immediately); tadyābat gṛhiṇīmāhūya saṃgītakamanutiṣṭhāmi Ś. 1 ; yāvadimāṃ chāyāmāśritya pratipālayāmi Ś. 3.  (c) As much as. (d) That, in order that. (e) Even, just.
Translation and Grammar Notes.Grammar: Here, we have a case of the gerundive. In Deshpande's Sanskrit Primer, he states that the gerunidive indicates what someone 'should do'. But Whitney's Grammar only translates it as 'to be done'. Monier Williams, in his Practical Sanskrit Grammar says, 'These suffixes yield a sense corresponding to the Latin Fut. Pass. Part. in dus, and the English able and ible, and most commonly denote 'obligation' or 'propriety' and 'fitness. It's also a bit of an awkward phrase because we have kair, but then the gerundive is intransitive and used impersonally (thus, the -am accusative singular neuter inflection). 'With whom (kair) ought there be a fighting (yoddhavyam) with me (mayā saha)?'

verses.sanskrit:
yotsyamānān avekṣe 'haṃ
ya ete 'tra samāgatāḥ
dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddher
yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yotsyamānān avekṣe ahaṃ
ye ete atra samāgatās
dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddhes
yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavas
verses.prabhupada: Let me see those who have come here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded son of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
verses.winthrop:
I behold those who are about to give battle,
Having come together here,
Wishing to do service in warefare
For the evil-minded son on Dhritarashtra (Duryodhanda).
verses.mitchell: I see these (who) will be fighting. Those who (are) assembled here desiring to do a favor for the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.

verses.sanskrit:
evam ukto hṛṣīkeśo
guḍākeśena bhārata
senayor ubhayor madhye
sthāpayitvā rathottamam
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
evam uktas hṛṣīkeśas
guḍākeśena bhārata
senayos ubhayos madhye
sthāpayitvā ratha-uttamam
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: O descendant of Bharata, having thus been addressed by Arjuna, Lord Kṛṣṇa drew up the fine chariot in the midst of the armies of both parties.
verses.winthrop:
Thus Krishna was addressed by Arjuna,
O Dhritarashtra,
Having caused the chief chartiot
To stand in the middle between the two armies.
verses.mitchell: O scion of Bharata, thus Hrishikesha was addressed by Gudakesha after stationing that best of chariots in the middle of the two armies.

verses.sanskrit:
bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ
sarveṣāṃ ca mahīkṣitām
uvāca pārtha paśyaitān
samavetān kurūn iti
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhatas
sarveṣām ca mahīkṣitām
uvāca pārtha paśyaitān
samavetān kurūn iti
verses.prabhupada: In the presence of Bhīṣma, Droṇa and all the other chieftains of the world, the Lord said, “Just behold, Pārtha, all the Kurus assembled here.”
verses.winthrop:
Before the eyes of Bhishma and Drona
And all these rules of the earth,
Arjuna said: Behold these
Kurus assembled.
verses.mitchell: In front of Bhishma, Drona, and all the kings of the earth, Partha said, 'Behold the assembled Kurus.'

verses.sanskrit:
tatrāpaśyat sthitān pārthaḥ
pitṛn atha pitāmahān
ācāryān mātulān bhrātṛn
putrān pautrān sakhīṃs tathā
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
tatra apaśyat sthitān pārthas
pitṛn atha pitāmahān
ācāryān mātulān bhrātṛn
putrān pautrān sakhīn tathā
verses.prabhupada: There Arjuna could see, within the midst of the armies of both parties, his fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and also his fathers-in-law and well-wishers.
verses.winthrop:
Arjuna saw standing there
Fathers, then grandfathers,
Teachers, maternal uncles, brothers,
Sons, grandsons, friends as well
verses.mitchell: There, Partha saw them standing: fathers, then grandfathers, teachers, uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and also friends.

verses.sanskrit:
śvaśurān suhṛdaś caiva
senayor ubhayor api
tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ
sarvān bandhūn avasthitān
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
śvaśurān suhṛdas ca eva
senayos ubhayos api
tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyas
sarvān bandhūn avasthitān
verses.prabhupada: When the son of Kuntī, Arjuna, saw all these different grades of friends and relatives, he became overwhelmed with compassion and spoke thus.
verses.winthrop:
Arjuna saw fathers-in-law, companions,
In the two armies,
And contemplated
All his kinsmen, arrayed.
verses.mitchell: ...fathers-in-law, and even well-wishers. Having seen them, all relatives, positioned in both armies, the son of Kunti...

verses.sanskrit:
kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo
viṣīdann idam abravīt
dṛṣṭvemaṃ sva-janaṃ kṛṣṇa
yuyutsuṃ samupasthitam
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
kṛpayā parayāviṣṭas
viṣīdan idam abravīt
dṛṣṭvā imam sva-janam kṛṣṇa
yuyutsum samupasthitam
verses.prabhupada: Arjuna said: My dear Kṛṣṇa, seeing my friends and relatives present before me in such a fighting spirit, I feel the limbs of my body quivering and my mouth drying up.
verses.winthrop:
Filled with infinite pity,
Despondent, he said this:
Having seen my own people, Krishna
Desiring to fight, approaching.
verses.mitchell: Filled with extreme compassion, he, lamenting, said this: O Krishna, seeing these kinsmen, arrived (and) desirous of battle...

verses.sanskrit:
sīdanti mama gātrāṇi
mukhañ ca pariśuṣyati
vepathuś ca śarīre me
roma-harṣaś ca jāyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
sīdanti mama gātrāṇi
mukhañ ca pariśuṣyati
vepathus ca śarīre me
roma-harṣas ca jāyate
verses.prabhupada: My whole body is trembling, my hair is standing on end, my bow Gāṇḍīva is slipping from my hand, and my skin is burning.
verses.winthrop:
My limbs sink down,
My mouth dries up,
My body trembles,
And my hair stands on end;
verses.mitchell: My limbs are sinking, my mouth is dry, there is a trembling in my body, and my hair is standing on end (literally: there is a coming of spikey hair).

verses.sanskrit: gāṇḍīvaṃ straṃsate hastāt tvak caiva paridahya tena ca śaknomy avasthātuṃ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: gāṇḍīvam straṃsate hastāt tvak ca eva paridahya tena ca śaknomi avasthātum bhramati iva ca me manas
verses.prabhupada: I am now unable to stand here any longer. I am forgetting myself, and my mind is reeling. I see only causes of misfortune, O Kṛṣṇa, killer of the Keśī demon.
verses.winthrop:
Gandiva (Arjuna's bow) falls from (my) hand,
My skin burns,
I am unable to remain as I am,
And my mind seems to reamble.
verses.mitchell: Gandiva (is) loosening from my hand, and (my) skin burns all over. I am not able to stand and my mind is reeling a bit.

verses.sanskrit:
nimittāni ca paśyāmi
viparītāni keśava
na ca śreyo 'nupaśyāmi
hatvā sva-janam āhave
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
nimittāni ca paśyāmi
viparītāni keśava
na ca śreyas anupaśyāmi
hatvā sva-janam āhave
verses.prabhupada: I do not see how any good can come from killing my own kinsmen in this battle, nor can I, my dear Kṛṣṇa, desire any subsequent victory, kingdom or happiness.
verses.winthrop:
I perceive inauspicious omens, O Krishna,
And I foresee misfortuned
In destoying my own people in battle.
verses.mitchell: I see distressful omens, Keshava, and I do not anticipate prosperity after killing (one's) own kinsman in battle.

verses.sanskrit:
na kāṅkṣe vijayaṃ kṛṣṇa
na ca rājyaṃ sukhāni ca
kiṃ no rājyena govinda
kiṃ bhogair jīvitena vā
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
na kāṅkṣe vijayam kṛṣṇa
na ca rājyam sukhāni ca
kim nas rājyena govinda
kim bhogais jīvitena vā
verses.prabhupada: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra?
verses.winthrop:
I do not desire victory, Krishna,
Nor kingship nor pleasures.
What is kingship to us, Krishna?
What are enjoyments, even life?
verses.mitchell: I don't want victory, Krishna, nor a kingdom and pleasures. What('s the point of) our kingdom, Govinda? What('s the point of) enjoyments or (even) life?

verses.sanskrit:
yeṣām arthe kāṅkṣitaṃ no
rājyaṃ bhogāḥ sukhāni ca
ta ime vasthitā yuddhe
prāṇāṃs tyaktvā dhanāni ca
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yeṣām arthe kāṅkṣitam nas
rājyam bhogās sukhāni ca
te ime avasthitā yuddhe
prāṇān tyaktvā dhanāni ca
verses.prabhupada: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra?
verses.winthrop:
Those for whose sake we desire
Kingship, enjoyments, and pleasures,
They are arrayed here in battle,
Abandoning their lives and riches.
verses.mitchell: For the sake of those whom (it was) our desired (object): kingdom, pleasures, and enjoyments. They are poised for battle, having given up their lives and riches.
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: Not easy to translate the first part. Arjuna is saying he wanted the objects of prosperity in order to enjoy them with the very people he had to kill to get them. Also, note the double pronoun (ta ime). It is a common construction, used to show emphasis, but literally, it just means 'they these!'

verses.sanskrit:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrās
tathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ
mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ
śyālāḥ sambandhinas tathā
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
ācāryās pitaras putrās
tathā eva ca pitāmahās
mātulās śvaśurās pautrās
śyālās sambandhinas tathā
verses.prabhupada: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra?
verses.winthrop:
Teachers, fathers, sons,
And also grandfathers,
Maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons,
Brothers-in-law, and other kinsmen.
verses.mitchell:
Teachers, fathers, sons,
And grandfathers as well. Maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, relatives, too.

verses.sanskrit:
etān na hantum icchhāmi
ghnato 'pi madhusūdana
api trailokya-rājyasya
hetoḥ kiṃ nu mahīkṛte
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
etān na hantum icchhāmi
ghnatas api madhusūdana
api trai-lokya-rājyasya
hetos kim nu mahī-kṛte
verses.prabhupada: O Govinda, of what avail to us are a kingdom, happiness or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed on this battlefield? O Madhusūdana, when teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law and other relatives are ready to give up their lives and properties and are standing before me, why should I wish to kill them, even though they might otherwise kill me? O maintainer of all living entities, I am not prepared to fight with them even in exchange for the three worlds, let alone this earth. What pleasure will we derive from killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra?
verses.winthrop:
I do not desire to kill
Them who are bent on killing, Krishna,
Even for the sovereignty of the three worlds. How much less then for the earth?
verses.mitchell: I don't want to kill them even (as) killers, Madhusudana. Even for the sake of sovereignty of the three words, what then on the created world

verses.sanskrit:
nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrān naḥ
kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana pāpam evāśrayed asmān
hatvaitān ātatāyinaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrān nas
kā prītis syāt janārdana
pāpam eva āśrayet asmān
hatvā etān ātatāyinas
verses.prabhupada: Sin will overcome us if we slay such aggressors. Therefore it is not proper for us to kill the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra and our friends. What should we gain, O Kṛṣṇa, husband of the goddess of fortune, and how could we be happy by killing our own kinsmen?
verses.winthrop:
What joy would it be for us
To strike down the sons of Dhritarashtra, O Krishna?
Evil thus would cling to us,
Having killed these aggressors.
verses.mitchell: After killing the Dhartarashtras, what pleasure would there be for us, Janardana? Sin would stick to us, having killed these men with their bows drawn.

verses.sanskrit:
tasmān nārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ
dhārtarāṣṭrān sva-bāndhavān
sva-janaṃ hi kathaṃ hatvā
sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
tasmān nārhās vayam hantum
dhārtarāṣṭrān sva-bāndhavān
sva-janam hi katham hatvā
sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava
verses.prabhupada: O Janārdana, although these men, their hearts overtaken by greed, see no fault in killing one’s family or quarreling with friends, why should we, who can see the crime in destroying a family, engage in these acts of sin?
verses.winthrop:
Therefore we are not justified in killing
The sons of Dhritarashtra, our own kinsmen.
How, having killed our own people,
Could we be happy, Krishna?
verses.mitchell: Therefore, we are not allowed to kill the Dhartarashtras, (our) own relatives. How, having killed (our) own people, could we be happy, Madhava?

verses.sanskrit:
yady apy ete na paśyanti
lobhopahata-cetasaḥ
kula-kṣaya-kṛtaṃ doṣaṃ
mitra-drohe ca pātakam
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yadi api ete na paśyanti
lobha-upahata-cetasas
kula-kṣaya-kṛtam doṣaṃ
mitra-drohe ca pātakam
verses.prabhupada: With the destruction of the dynasty, the eternal family tradition is vanquished, and thus the rest of the family becomes involved in irreligion.
verses.winthrop:
Even if those
Whose thoughts are overpowered by greed do not perceive
The wrong caused by the destruction of the family,
And the crime of treachery to friends.
verses.mitchell: Even if these (relatives) do not see, their minds overpowered by greed, the evil which destroys the family, and the crime in treachery to a friend.

verses.sanskrit:
kathaṃ na jñeyam asmābhiḥ
pāpād asmān nivartitum
kula-kṣaya-kṛtaṃ doṣaṃ
prapaśyadbhir janārdana
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
katham na jñeyam asmābhis
pāpāt asmān nivartitum
kula-kṣaya-kṛtam doṣam
prapaśyadbhis janārdana
verses.prabhupada: When irreligion is prominent in the family, O Kṛṣṇa, the women of the family become polluted, and from the degradation of womanhood, O descendant of Vṛṣṇi, comes unwanted progeny.
verses.winthrop:
Why should we not know enough
to turn back from this evil,
Through discernment of the wrong caused
By the destruction of the family, O Krishna?
verses.mitchell: How is it not to be known by us, via (our) sensibilities, to turn away from this sin as an evil that causes the destruction of the family, Janardana?

verses.sanskrit:
kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti
kula-dharmāḥ sanātanāḥ
dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnam
adharmo 'bhibhavaty uta
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti
kula-dharmās sanātanās
dharme naṣṭe kulam kṛtsnam
adharmas abhibhavati uta
verses.prabhupada: An increase of unwanted population certainly causes hellish life both for the family and for those who destroy the family tradition. The ancestors of such corrupt families fall down, because the performances for offering them food and water are entirely stopped.
verses.winthrop:
In the destruction of the family,
The ancient family laws vanish;
When the law has perished,
Lawlessness overpowers the entire family also.
verses.mitchell: When (there is) familial-destruction, the eternal family dharmas are lost. When dharma is destroyed, the entire family becomes irreligious as well.
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: Note the locative absolute and general meaning.

verses.sanskrit:
adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa
praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ
strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya
jāyate varṇa-saṅkaraḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
adharma-abhibhavāt kṛṣṇa
praduṣyanti kula-striyas
strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya
jāyate varṇa-saṅkaras
verses.prabhupada: By the evil deeds of those who destroy the family tradition and thus give rise to unwanted children, all kinds of community projects and family welfare activities are devastated.
verses.winthrop:
Because of the ascendency of lawlessness, Krishna,
The family women are corrupted;
When women are corrupted, O Krishna,
The intermixture of caste is born.
verses.mitchell: From the predominance of irreligion, O Krishna, the family women are corrupted. When the women (are) corrupted, descendent of Vrishni, the mixing of caste prevails.

verses.sanskrit:
saṅkaro narakāyaiva
kula-ghnānāṃ kulasya ca
patanti pitaro hy eṣāṃ
lupta-piṇḍodaka-kriyāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
saṅkaras narakāya eva
kula-ghnānām kulasya ca
patanti pitaras hi eṣāṃ
lupta-piṇḍodaka-kriyās
verses.prabhupada: O Kṛṣṇa, maintainer of the people, I have heard by disciplic succession that those whose family traditions are destroyed dwell always in hell.
verses.winthrop:
Intermixture brings to hell
The family destroyers and the family, too;
The ancestors of these indeed fall,
Deprived of offerings of rice and water.
verses.mitchell: Mixture to hell

verses.sanskrit:
doṣair etaiḥ kula-ghnānāṃ
varṇa-saṅkara-kārakaiḥ
utsādyante jāti-dharmāḥ
kula-dharmāś ca śāśvatāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
doṣais etais kula-ghnānām
varṇa-saṅkara-kārakais
utsādyante jāti-dharmās
kula-dharmās ca śāśvatās
verses.prabhupada: Alas, how strange it is that we are preparing to commit greatly sinful acts. Driven by the desire to enjoy royal happiness, we are intent on killing our own kinsmen.
verses.winthrop:
By these wrongs of the family destroyers,
Producing intermixture of caste,
Caste duties are abolished,
And eternal family laws also.
verses.mitchell: By these sins of family-killing, by the creation of caste mixing, innate duties and all family traditions are destroyed.
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: The word ghna can be translated as 'killer' or 'killing'. It is tempting simply to translate dharma as is.

verses.sanskrit:
utsanna-kula-dharmāṇāṃ
manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana
narake niyataṃ vāso
bhavatīty anuśuśruma
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
utsanna-kula-dharmāṇām
manuṣyāṇām janārdana
narake niyatam vāsas
bhavati iti anuśuśruma
verses.prabhupada: Better for me if the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, weapons in hand, were to kill me unarmed and unresisting on the battlefield.
verses.winthrop:
Men whose family laws have been obliterated,
O Krishna,
Dwell indefinitely in hell,
Thus we have heard repeatedly,
verses.mitchell: For the family-tradition-destroyed men, O Janardana, there is eternal residence in hell, so we've been told.
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: The prefix anu- in anu-śuśruma can have a meaning of 'repeatedly' or 'in succession' This gives it a sense of something being passed down over the years.

verses.sanskrit:
aho bata mahat pāpaṃ
kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam
yad rājya-sukha-lobhena
hantuṃ sva-janam udyatāḥ
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
verses.winthrop:
Ah! Alas! We are resolved
To do a great evil,
Which is to be intent on killing
Our own people, through greed for royal pleasures.
verses.mitchell: Oh, wow. We('re) determined to commit great sin because (we're) prepared to kill (our) own kinsmen.
verses.Translation and Grammar Notes: Aho bata is a pair of interjections. They can be translated with a variety of English interjections.

verses.sanskrit:
yadi mām apratīkāram
aśastraṃ śastra-pāṇayaḥ
dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyus
tan me kṣemataraṃ bhavet
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
yadi mām apratīkāram
aśastram śastra-pāṇayas
dhārtarāṣṭrās raṇe hanyus
tan me kṣemataram bhavet
verses.prabhupada: Better for me if the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, weapons in hand, were to kill me unarmed and unresisting on the battlefield.
verses.winthrop:
If the armed sons of Dhritarashtra
Should kill me in battle
While I was unresisting and unarmed,
This would be a greater happiness for me.
verses.mitchell: If the Dhartarashtras, weapons in-hand, should kill me in battle, non-reactive, that would be more comforting to me.

verses.sanskrit:
evam uktvārjunaḥ saṅkhye
rathopastha upāviśat
visṛjya saśaraṃ cāpaṃ
śoka-saṃvigna-mānasaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed:
evam uktvā arjunas saṅkhye
ratha-upasthe upāviśat
visṛjya saśaram cāpam
śoka-saṃvigna-mānasas
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
verses.winthrop:
Thus having spoken on the battlefield,
Arjuna sat down upon the seat of the chariot,
Throwing down both arrow and bow,
With a heart overcome by sorrow.
verses.mitchell: Having spoken thus, Arjuna, (while) at war, (and) stationed on the chariot, sat down after letting loose (his) arrow and bow, (his) mind fallen into sorrow.

verses.sanskrit: sañjaya uvāca taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭam aśru-pūrṇākulekṣaṇam viṣīdantam idaṃ vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: sañjaya uvāca taṃ tathā kṛpayā aviṣṭam aśru-pūrṇa-ākula-īkṣaṇam viṣīdantam idaṃ vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: Seeing Arjuna full of compassion, his mind depressed, his eyes full of tears, Madhusūdana, Kṛṣṇa, spoke the following words.
verses.winthrop:
Sanjaya spoke:
To him thus overcome by pity, despairing,
Whose eyes were filled with tears and downcast,
Krishna spoke these words:
verses.mitchell: Sanjaya said: At that time, Madhusudana spoke this utterance to the teary, depressed eyed, lamenting one, overcome with compassion.

verses.sanskrit: śrī bhagavān uvāca kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṃ viṣame samupasthitam anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrtikaram arjuna
verses.sanskrit-parsed: śrī bhagavān uvāca kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṃ viṣame samupasthitam anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrtikaram arjuna
verses.prabhupada: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: My dear Arjuna, how have these impurities come upon you? They are not at all befitting a man who knows the value of life. They lead not to higher planets but to infamy.
verses.winthrop:
The Blessed Lord spoke:
Whence has this timidity of yours
Come to you in the time of danger?
It is not acceptable in you, does not lead to heaven,
And causes disgrace, Arjuna.
verses.mitchell: Shri Bhagavan said: How has this impurity befallen you (while) in danger? (It is) enjoyed by the unhonorable, (the) ungodly, (and the) the cause of infamy, Arjuna.

Translation and Grammar Notes.1: There are 72 instances of kaśmala in the DCS, 59 of which are Mahabharata.
Translation and Grammar Notes.2: Notice the conjoined ideas at the end of this verse. There isn't always a conjunction joining them.

verses.sanskrit: klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate kṣudraṃ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha paraṃtapa
verses.sanskrit-parsed: klaibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate kṣudraṃ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha paraṃtapa
verses.prabhupada: O son of Pṛthā, do not yield to this degrading impotence. It does not become you. Give up such petty weakness of heart and arise, O chastiser of the enemy.
verses.winthrop:
Do not become a coward, Arjuna.
This is not suitable to you.
Abandoning base faintheartedness,
Stand up, Arjuna!
verses.mitchell: Don't go getting weak, Partha. This doesn't become you. Having given up trifling weakness of heart, arise, O scorcher of the enemy!

verses.sanskrit: arjuna uvāca kathaṃ bhīṣmam ahaṃ sāṅkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāv ari-sūdana
verses.sanskrit-parsed: arjuna uvāca kathaṃ bhīṣmam ahaṃ sāṅkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāv ari-sūdana
verses.prabhupada: Arjuna said: O killer of enemies, O killer of Madhu, how can I counterattack with arrows in battle men like Bhīṣma and Droṇa, who are worthy of my worship?
verses.winthrop:
Arjuna spoke:
How can I kill in battle
Bhishma and Drona, O Krishna? How can I fight with arrows against
These two venerable men, O Krishna?
verses.mitchell: Arjuna said: How am I to counter attack with arrows in battle Bhishma and Drona, Madhusudana? (They are) worthy of reverence, Arisudana.

verses.sanskrit: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyam apīha loke hatvārtha-kāmāṃs tu gurun ihaiva bhuñjjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān
verses.sanskrit-parsed: gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyam apīha loke hatvārtha-kāmāṃs tu gurun ihaiva bhuñjjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān
verses.prabhupada: It would be better to live in this world by begging than to live at the cost of the lives of great souls who are my teachers. Even though desiring worldly gain, they are superiors. If they are killed, everything we enjoy will be tainted with blood.
verses.winthrop:
Indeed, instead of slaying these noble gurus
It would be preferable to live on alms here on earth;
Having slain the gurus, with desire for worldly gain,
I would enjoy here on earth delights smeared with blood.
verses.mitchell: Having killed great authorities, gurus, (it is) better to enjoy begged alms here on earth. Having killed gurus for the purpose of enjoyments here, I would be enjoying wealth tainted with blood.

verses.sanskrit: na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te 'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: na ca etad vidmas kataran no garīyas yad vā jayema yadi vā nas jayeyuḥ yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te avasthitās pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrās
verses.prabhupada: Nor do we know which is better  conquering them or being conquered by them. If we killed the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, we should not care to live. Yet they are now standing before us on the battlefield.
verses.winthrop:
And this we do not know: which for us is preferable,
Whether we should conquer them or
they should conquer us.
The sons of Dhritarashtra, having
killed whom we would not wish to live,
Are standing before us.
verses.mitchell: Nor do we even know this, which (of the two) is better for us, either we prevail or they conquer us, (those) whom after killing we (are) not desirous of life, they, the Dhartarashtras, are situated before us.

verses.sanskrit: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasaṃmūḍhacetāḥ yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṃ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te 'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: kārpaṇya-doṣa-upahata-sva-bhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharma-saṃmūḍha-cetāḥ yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṃ brūhi tan me śiṣyas te ahaṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam
verses.prabhupada: Now I am confused about my duty and have lost all composure because of miserly weakness. In this condition I am asking You to tell me for certain what is best for me. Now I am Your disciple, and a soul surrendered unto You. Please instruct me.
verses.winthrop:
My own being is overcome by pity and weakness.
My mind is confused as to my duty. I ask you
Which is preferable, for certain?
Tell that to me, your pupil. Correct me,
I beg you.
verses.mitchell: (In a) state overcome with miserly weakness, a mind confused about duty, I'm asking you. Tell me this. I am your student. You instruct me, a suppliant one.

verses.sanskrit: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇām api cādhipatyam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām avāpya bhūmāv asapatnam ṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇām api cādhipatyam
verses.prabhupada: I can find no means to drive away this grief which is drying up my senses. I will not be able to dispel it even if I win a prosperous, unrivaled kingdom on earth with sovereignty like the demigods in heaven.
verses.winthrop:
Indeed, I do not see what will dispel
This sorrow of mine which dries up my senses,
Even if I should obtain on earth unrivaled and
Prosperous royal power, or even the
sovereignty of the gods.

verses.sanskrit: sañjaya uvāca evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ paraṃtapaḥ na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha
verses.sanskrit-parsed: sañjaya uvāca evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ paraṃtapaḥ na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha
verses.prabhupada: Sañjaya said: Having spoken thus, Arjuna, chastiser of enemies, told Kṛṣṇa, “Govinda, I shall not fight,” and fell silent.
verses.winthrop:
Sanjaya spoke:
Thus having addressed Krishna,
Arjuna said,
'I shall not fight,'
And having spoken, he became silent.
verses.mitchell: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, Gudakesha, scorcher of the foe, said, 'O Govinda, I will not fight.'

verses.sanskrit: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṃ vacaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṃ vacaḥ
verses.prabhupada: O descendant of Bharata, at that time Kṛṣṇa, smiling, in the midst of both the armies, spoke the following words to the grief-stricken Arjuna.
verses.winthrop:
To him, the dejected Arjuna, Krishna,
Beginning to laugh, O Dhritarashtra,
In the middle between the two armies,
Spoke these words:
verses.mitchell: O scion of Bharata, Hrishikesha, in the middle of the two armies, smilingly said this word to the lamenting one.

verses.sanskrit: śrī bhagavān uvāca aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṃ prajñāvādāṃś ca bhāṣase gatāsūn agatāsūṃś ca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: śrī bhagavān uvāca aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṃ prajñāvādāṃś ca bhāṣase gatāsūn agatāsūṃś ca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
verses.prabhupada: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: While speaking learned words, you are mourning for what is not worthy of grief. Those who are wise lament neither for the living nor for the dead.
verses.winthrop:
You have mourned those that should not be mourned,
And you speak words as if with wisdom;
The wise do not mourn for the dead or for the living.
verses.mitchell: Shri Bhagavan spoke: You were lamenting unlamentable (things), yet you speak words of wisdom. The wise do not lament those with and without breath (the living and the dead).

verses.sanskrit: natv evāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param
verses.sanskrit-parsed: natv evāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param
verses.prabhupada: Never was there a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor all these kings; nor in the future shall any of us cease to be.

verses.sanskrit: dehinosmin yathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā tathā dehāntaraprāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: dehinosmin yathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā tathā dehāntaraprāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
verses.prabhupada: As the embodied soul continuously passes, in this body, from boyhood to youth to old age, the soul similarly passes into another body at death. A sober person is not bewildered by such a change.

verses.sanskrit: mātrāsparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ āgamāpāyinonityās tāṃs titikṣasva bhārata
verses.sanskrit-parsed: mātrāsparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ āgamāpāyinonityās tāṃs titikṣasva bhārata
verses.prabhupada: O son of Kuntī, the nonpermanent appearance of happiness and distress, and their disappearance in due course, are like the appearance and disappearance of winter and summer seasons. They arise from sense perception, O scion of Bharata, and one must learn to tolerate them without being disturbed.

verses.sanskrit: yaṃ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ somṛtatvāya kalpate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yaṃ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ somṛtatvāya kalpate
verses.prabhupada: O best among men [Arjuna], the person who is not disturbed by happiness and distress and is steady in both is certainly eligible for liberation.

verses.sanskrit: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ ubhayor api dṛṣṭo.antas tv anayos tattvadarśibhiḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ ubhayor api dṛṣṭo.antas tv anayos tattvadarśibhiḥ
verses.prabhupada: Those who are seers of the truth have concluded that of the nonexistent [the material body] there is no endurance and of the eternal [the soul] there is no change. This they have concluded by studying the nature of both.

verses.sanskrit: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṃ tatam vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṃ tatam vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati
verses.prabhupada: That which pervades the entire body you should know to be indestructible. No one is able to destroy that imperishable soul.

verses.sanskrit: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ anāśinoprameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata
verses.sanskrit-parsed: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ anāśinoprameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata
verses.prabhupada: The material body of the indestructible, immeasurable and eternal living entity is sure to come to an end; therefore, fight, O descendant of Bharata.

verses.sanskrit: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaś cainaṃ manyate hatam ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaś cainaṃ manyate hatam ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate
verses.prabhupada: Neither he who thinks the living entity the slayer nor he who thinks it slain is in knowledge, for the self slays not nor is slain.

verses.sanskrit: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ ajo nityaḥ śāśvatoyaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
verses.sanskrit-parsed: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ ajo nityaḥ śāśvatoyaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
verses.prabhupada: For the soul there is neither birth nor death at any time. He has not come into being, does not come into being, and will not come into being. He is unborn, eternal, ever-existing and primeval. He is not slain when the body is slain.

verses.sanskrit: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enam ajam avyayam kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enam ajam avyayam kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam
verses.prabhupada: O Pārtha, how can a person who knows that the soul is indestructible, eternal, unborn and immutable kill anyone or cause anyone to kill?

verses.sanskrit: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naroparāṇi tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāni anyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī
verses.sanskrit-parsed: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naroparāṇi tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāni anyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī
verses.prabhupada: As a person puts on new garments, giving up old ones, the soul similarly accepts new material bodies, giving up the old and useless ones.

verses.sanskrit: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ na cainaṃ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ na cainaṃ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
verses.prabhupada: The soul can never be cut to pieces by any weapon, nor burned by fire, nor moistened by water, nor withered by the wind.

verses.sanskrit: acchedyoyam adāhyoyam akledyośoṣya eva ca nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇur acaloyaṃ sanātanaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: acchedyoyam adāhyoyam akledyośoṣya eva ca nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇur acaloyaṃ sanātanaḥ
verses.prabhupada: This individual soul is unbreakable and insoluble, and can be neither burned nor dried. He is everlasting, present everywhere, unchangeable, immovable and eternally the same.

verses.sanskrit: avyaktoyam acintyoyam avikaryoyam ucyate tasmād evaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitum arhasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: avyaktoyam acintyoyam avikaryoyam ucyate tasmād evaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitum arhasi
verses.prabhupada: It is said that the soul is invisible, inconceivable and immutable. Knowing this, you should not grieve for the body.

verses.sanskrit: atha cainaṃ nityajātaṃ nityaṃ vā manyase mṛtam tathāpi tvaṃ mahā-bāho naivaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: atha cainaṃ nityajātaṃ nityaṃ vā manyase mṛtam tathāpi tvaṃ mahā-bāho naivaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.prabhupada: If, however, you think that the soul [or the symptoms of life] will always be born and die forever, you still have no reason to lament, O mighty-armed.

verses.sanskrit: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca tasmād aparihāryerthe na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca tasmād aparihāryerthe na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.prabhupada: One who has taken his birth is sure to die, and after death one is sure to take birth again. Therefore, in the unavoidable discharge of your duty, you should not lament.

verses.sanskrit: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata avyaktanidhanāny eva tatra kā paridevanā
verses.sanskrit-parsed: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata avyaktanidhanāny eva tatra kā paridevanā
verses.prabhupada: All created beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their interim state, and unmanifest again when annihilated. So what need is there for lamentation?

verses.sanskrit: āścaryavat paśyati kaścid enam āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ āścaryavac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaścit
verses.sanskrit-parsed: āścaryavat paśyati kaścid enam āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ āścaryavac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti śrutvāpy enaṃ veda na caiva kaścit
verses.prabhupada: Some look on the soul as amazing, some describe him as amazing, and some hear of him as amazing, while others, even after hearing about him, cannot understand him at all.

verses.sanskrit: dehī nityam avadhyoyaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: dehī nityam avadhyoyaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitum arhasi
verses.prabhupada: O descendant of Bharata, he who dwells in the body can never be slain. Therefore you need not grieve for any living being.

verses.sanskrit: svadharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyonyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: svadharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyonyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
verses.prabhupada: Considering your specific duty as a kṣatriya, you should know that there is no better engagement for you than fighting on religious principles; and so there is no need for hesitation.

verses.sanskrit: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāram apāvṛtam sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāram apāvṛtam sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
verses.prabhupada: O Pārtha, happy are the kṣatriyas to whom such fighting opportunities come unsought, opening for them the doors of the heavenly planets.

verses.sanskrit: atha cet tvam imaṃ dhārmyaṃ saṅgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: atha cet tvam imaṃ dhārmyaṃ saṅgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.prabhupada: If, however, you do not perform your religious duty of fighting, then you will certainly incur sins for neglecting your duties and thus lose your reputation as a fighter.

verses.sanskrit: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti tevyayām saṃbhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti tevyayām saṃbhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate
verses.prabhupada: People will always speak of your infamy, and for a respectable person, dishonor is worse than death.

verses.sanskrit: bhayād raṇād uparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: bhayād raṇād uparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
verses.prabhupada: The great generals who have highly esteemed your name and fame will think that you have left the battlefield out of fear only, and thus they will consider you insignificant.

verses.sanskrit: avācyavādāṃś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ nindantas tava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim
verses.sanskrit-parsed: avācyavādāṃś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ nindantas tava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim
verses.prabhupada: Your enemies will describe you in many unkind words and scorn your ability. What could be more painful for you?

verses.sanskrit: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ
verses.prabhupada: O son of Kuntī, either you will be killed on the battlefield and attain the heavenly planets, or you will conquer and enjoy the earthly kingdom. Therefore, get up with determination and fight.

verses.sanskrit: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpam avāpsyasi
verses.prabhupada: Do thou fight for the sake of fighting, without considering happiness or distress, loss or gain, victory or defeat  and by so doing you shall never incur sin.

verses.sanskrit: eṣā tebhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṃ śṛṇu buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: eṣā tebhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṃ śṛṇu buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi
verses.prabhupada: Thus far I have described this knowledge to you through analytical study. Now listen as I explain it in terms of working without fruitive results. O son of Pṛthā, when you act in such knowledge you can free yourself from the bondage of works.

verses.sanskrit: nehābhikramanāśosti pratyavāyo na vidyate svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
verses.sanskrit-parsed: nehābhikramanāśosti pratyavāyo na vidyate svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
verses.prabhupada: In this endeavor there is no loss or diminution, and a little advancement on this path can protect one from the most dangerous type of fear.

verses.sanskrit: vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kurunandana bahuśākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayovyavasāyinām
verses.sanskrit-parsed: vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kurunandana bahuśākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayovyavasāyinām
verses.prabhupada: Those who are on this path are resolute in purpose, and their aim is one. O beloved child of the Kurus, the intelligence of those who are irresolute is many-branched.

verses.sanskrit: yām imāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ vedavādaratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yām imāṃ puṣpitāṃ vācaṃ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ vedavādaratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādinaḥ
verses.prabhupada: Men of small knowledge are very much attached to the flowery words of the Vedas, which recommend various fruitive activities for elevation to heavenly planets, resultant good birth, power, and so forth.

verses.sanskrit: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati
verses.prabhupada: Being desirous of sense gratification and opulent life, they say that there is nothing more than this.

verses.sanskrit: bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
verses.prabhupada: In the minds of those who are too attached to sense enjoyment and material opulence, and who are bewildered by such things, the resolute determination for devotional service to the Supreme Lord does not take place.

verses.sanskrit: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna nirdvandvo nityasatvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān
verses.sanskrit-parsed: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna nirdvandvo nityasatvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān
verses.prabhupada: The Vedas deal mainly with the subject of the three modes of material nature. O Arjuna, become transcendental to these three modes. Be free from all dualities and from all anxieties for gain and safety, and be established in the self.

verses.sanskrit: yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yāvān artha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
verses.prabhupada: All purposes served by a small well can at once be served by a great reservoir of water. Similarly, all the purposes of the Vedas can be served to one who knows the purpose behind them.

verses.sanskrit: karmaṇy evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana mā karmaphalahetur bhūr mā te saṅgostv akarmaṇi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: karmaṇy evādhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana mā karmaphalahetur bhūr mā te saṅgostv akarmaṇi
verses.prabhupada: You have a right to perform your prescribed duty, but you are not entitled to the fruits of action. Never consider yourself the cause of the results of your activities, and never be attached to not doing your duty.

verses.sanskrit: yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā dhanañjaya siddhyasiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṃ yoga ucyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yogasthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā dhanañjaya siddhyasiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṃ yoga ucyate
verses.prabhupada: Perform your duty equipoised, O Arjuna, abandoning all attachment to success or failure. Such equanimity is called yoga.

verses.sanskrit: dūreṇa hy avaraṃ karma buddhiyogād dhanañjaya buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phalahetavaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: dūreṇa hy avaraṃ karma buddhiyogād dhanañjaya buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phalahetavaḥ
verses.prabhupada: O Dhanañjaya, keep all abominable activities far distant by devotional service, and in that consciousness surrender unto the Lord. Those who want to enjoy the fruits of their work are misers.

verses.sanskrit: buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: buddhiyukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛtaduṣkṛte tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karmasu kauśalam
verses.prabhupada: A man engaged in devotional service rids himself of both good and bad reactions even in this life. Therefore strive for yoga, which is the art of all work.

verses.sanskrit: karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ janmabandhavinirmuktāḥ padaṃ gacchhanty anāmayam
verses.sanskrit-parsed: karmajaṃ buddhiyuktā hi phalaṃ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ janmabandhavinirmuktāḥ padaṃ gacchhanty anāmayam
verses.prabhupada: By thus engaging in devotional service to the Lord, great sages or devotees free themselves from the results of work in the material world. In this way they become free from the cycle of birth and death and attain the state beyond all miseries [by going back to Godhead].

verses.sanskrit: yadā te mohakalilaṃ buddhir vyatitariṣyati tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yadā te mohakalilaṃ buddhir vyatitariṣyati tadā gantāsi nirvedaṃ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
verses.prabhupada: When your intelligence has passed out of the dense forest of delusion, you shall become indifferent to all that has been heard and all that is to be heard.

verses.sanskrit: śrutivipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: śrutivipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā samādhāv acalā buddhis tadā yogam avāpsyasi
verses.prabhupada: When your mind is no longer disturbed by the flowery language of the Vedas, and when it remains fixed in the trance of self-realization, then you will have attained the divine consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
verses.sanskrit-parsed: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
verses.prabhupada: Arjuna said: O Kṛṣṇa, what are the symptoms of one whose consciousness is thus merged in transcendence? How does he speak, and what is his language? How does he sit, and how does he walk?

verses.sanskrit: śrī bhagavān uvāca prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manogatān ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthitaprajñas tadocyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: śrī bhagavān uvāca prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha manogatān ātmany evātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthitaprajñas tadocyate
verses.prabhupada: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: O Pārtha, when a man gives up all varieties of desire for sense gratification, which arise from mental concoction, and when his mind, thus purified, finds satisfaction in the self alone, then he is said to be in pure transcendental consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: duḥkheṣv anudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ sthitadhīr munir ucyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: duḥkheṣv anudvignamanāḥ sukheṣu vigataspṛhaḥ vītarāgabhayakrodhaḥ sthitadhīr munir ucyate
verses.prabhupada: One who is not disturbed in mind even amidst the threefold miseries or elated when there is happiness, and who is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady mind.

verses.sanskrit: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tattatprāpya śubhāśubham nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yaḥ sarvatrānabhisnehas tattatprāpya śubhāśubham nābhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.prabhupada: In the material world, one who is unaffected by whatever good or evil he may obtain, neither praising it nor despising it, is firmly fixed in perfect knowledge.

verses.sanskrit: yadā saṃharate cāyaṃ kūrmoṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yadā saṃharate cāyaṃ kūrmoṅgānīva sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.prabhupada: One who is able to withdraw his senses from sense objects, as the tortoise draws its limbs within the shell, is firmly fixed in perfect consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ rasavarjaṃ rasopy asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ rasavarjaṃ rasopy asya paraṃ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
verses.prabhupada: Though the embodied soul may be restricted from sense enjoyment, the taste for sense objects remains. But, ceasing such engagements by experiencing a higher taste, he is fixed in consciousness.

verses.sanskrit: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṃ manaḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yatato hy api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṃ manaḥ
verses.prabhupada: The senses are so strong and impetuous, O Arjuna, that they forcibly carry away the mind even of a man of discrimination who is endeavoring to control them.

verses.sanskrit: tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta matparaḥ vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.sanskrit-parsed: tāni sarvāṇi saṃyamya yukta āsīta matparaḥ vaśe hi yasyendriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.prabhupada: One who restrains his senses, keeping them under full control, and fixes his consciousness upon Me, is known as a man of steady intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: dhyāyato viṣayān puṃsaḥ saṅgas teṣūpajāyate saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodhobhijāyate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: dhyāyato viṣayān puṃsaḥ saṅgas teṣūpajāyate saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodhobhijāyate
verses.prabhupada: While contemplating the objects of the senses, a person develops attachment for them, and from such attachment lust develops, and from lust anger arises.

verses.sanskrit: krodhād bhavati saṃmohaḥ saṃmohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ smṛtibhraṃśād buddhināśo buddhināśāt praṇaśyati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: krodhād bhavati saṃmohaḥ saṃmohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ smṛtibhraṃśād buddhināśo buddhināśāt praṇaśyati
verses.prabhupada: From anger, complete delusion arises, and from delusion bewilderment of memory. When memory is bewildered, intelligence is lost, and when intelligence is lost one falls down again into the material pool.

verses.sanskrit: rāgadveṣavimuktais tu viṣayān indriyaiś caran ātmavaśyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigacchati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: rāgadveṣavimuktais tu viṣayān indriyaiś caran ātmavaśyair vidheyātmā prasādam adhigacchati
verses.prabhupada: But a person free from all attachment and aversion and able to control his senses through regulative principles of freedom can obtain the complete mercy of the Lord.

verses.sanskrit: prasāde sarvaduḥkhānāṃ hānir asyopajāyate prasannacetaso hy āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
verses.sanskrit-parsed: prasāde sarvaduḥkhānāṃ hānir asyopajāyate prasannacetaso hy āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
verses.prabhupada: For one thus satisfied [in Kṛṣṇa consciousness], the threefold miseries of material existence exist no longer; in such satisfied consciousness, one’s intelligence is soon well established.

verses.sanskrit: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
verses.sanskrit-parsed: nāsti buddhir ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
verses.prabhupada: One who is not connected with the Supreme [in Kṛṣṇa consciousness] can have neither transcendental intelligence nor a steady mind, without which there is no possibility of peace. And how can there be any happiness without peace?

verses.sanskrit: indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yan manonuvidhīyate tad asya harati prajñāṃ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi
verses.sanskrit-parsed: indriyāṇāṃ hi caratāṃ yan manonuvidhīyate tad asya harati prajñāṃ vāyur nāvam ivāmbhasi
verses.prabhupada: As a strong wind sweeps away a boat on the water, even one of the roaming senses on which the mind focuses can carry away a man’s intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.sanskrit-parsed: tasmād yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ indriyāṇīndriyārthebhyas tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
verses.prabhupada: Therefore, O mighty-armed, one whose senses are restrained from their objects is certainly of steady intelligence.

verses.sanskrit: yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ
verses.sanskrit-parsed: yā niśā sarvabhūtānāṃ tasyāṃ jāgarti saṃyamī yasyāṃ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyato muneḥ
verses.prabhupada: What is night for all beings is the time of awakening for the self-controlled; and the time of awakening for all beings is night for the introspective sage.

verses.sanskrit: āpūryamāṇam acalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat tadvat kāmā yaṃ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāmakāmī
verses.sanskrit-parsed: āpūryamāṇam acalapratiṣṭhaṃ samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat tadvat kāmā yaṃ praviśanti sarve sa śāntim āpnoti na kāmakāmī
verses.prabhupada: A person who is not disturbed by the incessant flow of desires  that enter like rivers into the ocean, which is ever being filled but is always still  can alone achieve peace, and not the man who strives to satisfy such desires.

verses.sanskrit: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṃś carati niḥspṛhaḥ nirmamo nirahaṃkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchhati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumāṃś carati niḥspṛhaḥ nirmamo nirahaṃkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchhati
verses.prabhupada: A person who has given up all desires for sense gratification, who lives free from desires, who has given up all sense of proprietorship and is devoid of false ego  he alone can attain real peace.

verses.sanskrit: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati sthitvāsyām antakālepi brahmanirvāṇam ṛcchati
verses.sanskrit-parsed: eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṃ prāpya vimuhyati sthitvāsyām antakālepi brahmanirvāṇam ṛcchati
verses.prabhupada: That is the way of the spiritual and godly life, after attaining which a man is not bewildered. If one is thus situated even at the hour of death, one can enter into the kingdom of God.

verses.sanskrit:
arjuna uvāca
jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te
matā buddhir janārdana
tat kiṃ karmaṇi ghore māṃ
niyojayasi keśava
verses.prabhupada: Arjuna said: O Janārdana, O Keśava, why do You want to engage me in this ghastly warfare, if You think that intelligence is better than fruitive work?

verses.sanskrit:
vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena
buddhiṃ mohayasīva me
tad ekaṃ vada niścitya
yena śreyo 'ham āpnuyām
verses.prabhupada: My intelligence is bewildered by Your equivocal instructions. Therefore, please tell me decisively which will be most beneficial for me.

verses.sanskrit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣṭhā
purā proktā mayānagha
jñānayogena sāṅkhyānāṃ
karma-yogena yoginām
verses.prabhupada: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: O sinless Arjuna, I have already explained that there are two classes of men who try to realize the self. Some are inclined to understand it by empirical, philosophical speculation, and others by devotional service.

verses.sanskrit:
na karmaṇām anārambhān
naiṣkarmyaṃ puruṣo 'śnute
na ca saṃnyasanād eva
siddhiṃ samadhigacchati
verses.prabhupada: Not by merely abstaining from work can one achieve freedom from reaction, nor by renunciation alone can one attain perfection.

verses.sanskrit:
na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api
jātu tiṣṭhaty akarmakṛt
kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma
sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ
verses.prabhupada: Everyone is forced to act helplessly according to the qualities he has acquired from the modes of material nature; therefore no one can refrain from doing something, not even for a moment.

verses.sanskrit:
karmendriyāṇi saṃyamya
ya āste manasā smaran
indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā
mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate
verses.prabhupada: One who restrains the senses of action but whose mind dwells on sense objects certainly deludes himself and is called a pretender.

verses.sanskrit:
yas tv indriyāṇi manasā
niyamyārabhate 'rjuna
karmaindriyaiḥ karma-yogam
asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
verses.prabhupada: On the other hand, if a sincere person tries to control the active senses by the mind and begins karma-yoga [in Kṛṣṇa consciousness] without attachment, he is by far superior.

verses.sanskrit:
niyataṃ kuru karma tvaṃ
karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ
śarīra-yātrāpi ca te
na prasidhyed akarmaṇaḥ
verses.prabhupada: Perform your prescribed duty, for doing so is better than not working. One cannot even maintain one’s physical body without work.

verses.sanskrit:
yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra
lokoyaṃ karma-bandhanaḥ
tad-arthaṃ karma kaunteya
muktasaṅgaḥ samācara
verses.prabhupada: Work done as a sacrifice for Viṣṇu has to be performed; otherwise work causes bondage in this material world. Therefore, O son of Kuntī, perform your prescribed duties for His satisfaction, and in that way you will always remain free from bondage.

verses.sanskrit:
saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā
purovāca prajāpatiḥ
anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vo 'stv iṣṭa-kāma-dhuk
verses.prabhupada: In the beginning of creation, the Lord of all creatures sent forth generations of men and demigods, along with sacrifices for Viṣṇu, and blessed them by saying, “Be thou happy by this yajña [sacrifice] because its performance will bestow upon you everything desirable for living happily and achieving liberation.”

verses.sanskrit:
devān bhāvayatānena
te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ
parasparaṃ bhāvayantaḥ
śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha
verses.prabhupada: The demigods, being pleased by sacrifices, will also please you, and thus, by cooperation between men and demigods, prosperity will reign for all.

verses.sanskrit:
iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devā
dāsyante yajñabhāvitāḥ
tair dattān apradāyaibhyo
yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
verses.prabhupada: In charge of the various necessities of life, the demigods, being satisfied by the performance of yajña [sacrifice], will supply all necessities to you. But he who enjoys such gifts without offering them to the demigods in return is certainly a thief.

verses.sanskrit:
yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ santo
mucyante sarvakilbiṣaiḥ
bhuñjate te tv aghaṃ pāpā
ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt
verses.prabhupada: The devotees of the Lord are released from all kinds of sins because they eat food which is offered first for sacrifice. Others, who prepare food for personal sense enjoyment, verily eat only sin.

verses.sanskrit:
annād bhavanti bhūtāni
parjanyād anna-saṃbhavaḥ
yajñād bhavati parjanyo
yajñaḥ karma-samudbhavaḥ
verses.prabhupada: All living bodies subsist on food grains, which are produced from rains. Rains are produced by performance of yajña [sacrifice], and yajña is born of prescribed duties.

verses.sanskrit:
karma brahmodbhavaṃ viddhi
brahmākṣara-samudbhavam
tasmāt sarvagataṃ brahma
nityaṃ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
verses.prabhupada: Regulated activities are prescribed in the Vedas, and the Vedas are directly manifested from the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Consequently the all-pervading Transcendence is eternally situated in acts of sacrifice.

verses.sanskrit:
evaṃ pravartitaṃ cakraṃ
nānuvartayatīha yaḥ
aghāyur indriyārāmo
moghaṃ pārtha sa jīvati
verses.prabhupada: My dear Arjuna, one who does not follow in human life the cycle of sacrifice thus established by the Vedas certainly leads a life full of sin. Living only for the satisfaction of the senses, such a person lives in vain.

verses.sanskrit:
yas tv ātmaratir eva syād
ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ
ātmany eva ca saṃtuṣṭas
tasya kāryaṃ na vidyate
verses.prabhupada: But for one who takes pleasure in the Self, whose human life is one of self-realization, and who is satisfied in the Self only, fully satiated – for him there is no duty.

verses.sanskrit:
naiva tasya kṛtenārtho
nākṛteneha kaścanana
cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu
kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ
verses.prabhupada: A self-realized man has no purpose to fulfill in the discharge of his prescribed duties, nor has he any reason not to perform such work. Nor has he any need to depend on any other living being.

verses.sanskrit:
tasmād asaktaḥ satataṃ
kāryaṃ karma samācara
asakto hy ācaran karma
param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ
verses.prabhupada: Therefore, without being attached to the fruits of activities, one should act as a matter of duty, for by working without attachment one attains the Supreme.

verses.sanskrit:
karmaṇaiva hi saṃsiddhim
āsthitā janakādayaḥ
loka-saṃgraham evāpi
saṃpaśyan kartum arhasi
verses.prabhupada: Kings such as Janaka attained perfection solely by performance of prescribed duties. Therefore, just for the sake of educating the people in general, you should perform your work.

verses.sanskrit:
yadyad ācarati śreṣṭhas
tat tad evetaro janaḥ
sa yat pramāṇaṃ kurute
lokas tad anuvartate
verses.prabhupada: Whatever action a great man performs, common men follow. And whatever standards he sets by exemplary acts, all the world pursues.

verses.sanskrit:
na me pārthāsti kartavyaṃ
triṣu lokeṣu kiṃcana
nānavāptam avāptavyaṃ
varta eva ca karmaṇi
